title: Speaker eyes multiple uses for gov’t clearances
text:
Speaker eyes multiple uses for gov’t clearances By Jess Diaz   
MANILA, Philippines - Speaker Pantaleon Alvarez wants government documents such as clearances from the National Bureau of Investigation (NBI), police and courts to be used for multiple purposes. 
In a radio interview, Alvarez revealed that he has met with NBI officials on how the agency’s clearance could be used for employment, obtaining a passport, securing a firearm or driver’s license, and similar documents. 
He said he has asked the officials to see how this could be accomplished. 
“I cannot understand why an NBI clearance issued for employment could not be used for securing a firearm license or for other transactions with the government. People have to go back to the agency again to obtain another clearance. We are inflicting too much suffering and pain on them,” he said. 
Alvarez said before one is issued an NBI clearance, he is usually required to obtain clearances from the courts and the prosecutor’s office as proof that he has no pending case. 
Alvarez noted that when a case is filed, the court or the prosecutor’s office “automatically sends the information to the NBI for record purposes.”   
“But when the complaint is dismissed, automatic transmittal of such information does not happen and the accused has to go to the court and the prosecutor’s office for clearances,” he said. 
Alvarez said there should be an internet connection among courts, prosecutors and the NBI, so that a person obtaining a clearance applies only with the NBI and does not have to go to the other agencies. 
“The same should be true with other frontline agencies like the Land Transportation Office and Philippine Statistics Office, where people secure birth certificates,” he said. 
He added that a birth certificate, like an NBI clearance, should be good for multiple uses. 
Alvarez pointed out that these government documents should remain useful for any purpose for their entire one-year expiration period. 
He stressed that if his initiative materializes, it would bring a big relief to people requiring clearances. 
He promised that the House of Representatives would give frontline agencies the necessary funds for online linkup with other offices. 
The government would spend for it so there would be no need to hire private contractors, he said.
